articles.headline: Macy’s Is Said to Receive Takeover Approach by Hudson’s Bay
articles.snippet: Once a retail titan, Macy’s has struggled to remain relevant as e-commerce and discount retailers have decimated the traditional brick-and-mortar business.
articles.abstract: Once a retail titan, Macy’s has struggled to remain relevant as e-commerce and discount retailers have decimated the traditional brick-and-mortar business.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Macy’s of today grew from the union of several great names in American retailing, including its namesake chain, Bloomingdale’s and Marshall Field’s.
articles.byline: By Michael J. de la Merced and Rachel Abrams

articles.headline: The Trump Effect: What’s an Investor to Do?
articles.snippet: Bombshell executive orders from the president have dampened investors’ hopes of quick economic growth, at least for now.
articles.abstract: Bombshell executive orders from the president have dampened investors’ hopes of quick economic growth, at least for now.
articles.lead_paragraph: When Donald J. Trump won the presidential election, investors seemed positively giddy about what he was going to do to improve the nation’s economy. Believing that his promises to reduce corporate taxes and curtail costly regulations would unleash economic growth, investors pushed stock indexes to new heights.

articles.headline: Trump Moves to Roll Back Obama-Era Financial Regulations
articles.snippet: The actions constituted a broad effort to loosen rules enacted after the financial crisis that restrict the way Wall Street can operate.
articles.abstract: The actions constituted a broad effort to loosen rules enacted after the financial crisis that restrict the way Wall Street can operate.
articles.lead_paragraph: President Trump on Friday moved to chisel away at the Obama administration’s legacy on financial regulation, announcing steps to revisit the rules enacted after the 2008 financial crisis and to back away from a measure intended to protect consumers from bad investment advice.
articles.byline: By Ben Protess and Julie Hirschfeld Davis

articles.headline: Court Temporarily Blocks Trump’s Travel Ban, and Airlines Are Told to Allow Passengers
articles.snippet: A judge in Seattle ordered a nationwide halt to the ban while a Boston court refused to extend a stay. Earlier the State Department said 60,000 visas had been revoked.
articles.abstract: A judge in Seattle ordered a nationwide halt to the ban while a Boston court refused to extend a stay. Earlier the State Department said 60,000 visas had been revoked.
articles.lead_paragraph: A federal judge in Seattle on Friday temporarily blocked President Trump’s week-old immigration order from being enforced nationwide, reopening America’s door to visa holders from seven predominantly Muslim countries and dealing the administration a humbling defeat.
articles.byline: By Nicholas Kulish, Caitlin Dickerson and Charlie Savage

articles.headline: China’s Intelligent Weaponry Gets Smarter
articles.snippet: The United States no longer has a strategic monopoly on a technology that is widely seen as the key factor in the next generation of warfare.
articles.abstract: The United States no longer has a strategic monopoly on a technology that is widely seen as the key factor in the next generation of warfare.
articles.lead_paragraph: Robert O. Work, the veteran defense official retained as deputy secretary by President Trump, calls them his “A.I. dudes.” The breezy moniker belies their serious task: The dudes have been a kitchen cabinet of sorts, and have advised Mr. Work as he has sought to reshape warfare by bringing artificial intelligence to the battlefield.
articles.byline: By John Markoff and Matthew Rosenberg

articles.headline: For Andrew Puzder, Labor Nominee, Fighting for Owners’ Interests Began Early
articles.snippet: As a young lawyer, Mr. Puzder led the defense for his boss, a famous mob lawyer and casino owner accused of squandering millions from his workers’ pension funds.
articles.abstract: As a young lawyer, Mr. Puzder led the defense for his boss, a famous mob lawyer and casino owner accused of squandering millions from his workers’ pension funds.
articles.lead_paragraph: Decades before President Trump nominated him to be labor secretary, Andrew Puzder went to battle with federal labor regulators in a Las Vegas courtroom.
articles.byline: By Russ Buettner and Noam Scheiber

articles.headline: Trust Records Show Trump Is Still Closely Tied to His Empire
articles.snippet: New documents on the president’s trust, set up to allay fears of conflicts of interest, show just how closely tied he remains to his business.
articles.abstract: New documents on the president’s trust, set up to allay fears of conflicts of interest, show just how closely tied he remains to his business.
articles.lead_paragraph: Just days before his inauguration, President-elect Donald J. Trump stood beside his tax lawyer at a Midtown Manhattan news conference as she announced that he planned to place his vast business holdings in a trust, a move she said would allay fears that he might exploit the Oval Office for personal gain.
articles.byline: By Susanne Craig and Eric Lipton

articles.headline: Foodies Know: Boulder Has Become a Hub for New Producers
articles.snippet: With a growing support network of brokers, distributors and investors, this city has allowed new companies to challenge the old guard in the food business.
articles.abstract: With a growing support network of brokers, distributors and investors, this city has allowed new companies to challenge the old guard in the food business.
articles.lead_paragraph: BOULDER, Colo. — Quinn Snacks was founded in Arlington, Mass., in 2011. The company’s goal was to “clean up” microwave popcorn, which had come under fire for the material used in its bags, and trans fats and other ingredients that many of today’s consumers find offensive.

articles.headline: Unease in Colombia, as Old Enemies Become New Neighbors
articles.snippet: Among the 7,000 FARC rebels surrendering their guns this year, those who have moved near La Paz, find townspeople with long memories are watching warily.
articles.abstract: Among the 7,000 FARC rebels surrendering their guns this year, those who have moved near La Paz, find townspeople with long memories are watching warily.
articles.lead_paragraph: LA PAZ, Colombia — The town’s name is Spanish for “peace.” The days to come will test how accurate that is.

articles.headline: His Doctors Were Stumped. Then He Took Over.
articles.snippet: After his rare disease baffled specialist after specialist, Dr. David Fajgenbaum dedicated himself to solving his own case.
articles.abstract: After his rare disease baffled specialist after specialist, Dr. David Fajgenbaum dedicated himself to solving his own case.
articles.lead_paragraph: They called him the Beast.

articles.headline: Not ‘Lone Wolves’ After All: How ISIS Guides World’s Terror Plots From Afar
articles.snippet: Terrorism planners in Syria and Iraq are using messaging apps to enable attacks across the world, right down to picking the targets and finding the guns.
articles.abstract: Terrorism planners in Syria and Iraq are using messaging apps to enable attacks across the world, right down to picking the targets and finding the guns.
articles.lead_paragraph: HYDERABAD, India — When the Islamic State identified a promising young recruit willing to carry out an attack in one of India’s major tech hubs, the group made sure to arrange everything down to the bullets he needed to kill victims.

articles.headline: Appeals Court Rejects Request to Immediately Restore Travel Ban
articles.snippet: The court’s decision against the Justice Department deepened the legal showdown over President Trump’s immigration order.
articles.abstract: The court’s decision against the Justice Department deepened the legal showdown over President Trump’s immigration order.
articles.lead_paragraph: WEST PALM BEACH, Fla. — A federal appeals court early Sunday rejected a request by the Justice Department to immediately restore President Trump’s targeted travel ban, deepening a legal showdown over his authority to tighten the nation’s borders in the name of protecting Americans from terrorism.

articles.headline: In Fall of Gorsuch’s Mother, a Painful Lesson in Politicking
articles.snippet: President Trump’s Supreme Court nominee learned from an early age about how caustic the nation’s political culture could be. He now faces his own test in Washington.
articles.abstract: President Trump’s Supreme Court nominee learned from an early age about how caustic the nation’s political culture could be. He now faces his own test in Washington.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Judge Neil M. Gorsuch’s first taste of rough-and-tumble Washington politics was bitter and lingering.
articles.byline: By Adam Liptak, Peter Baker, Nicholas Fandos and Julie Turkewitz

articles.headline: G.O.P. Hurries to Slash Oil and Gas Rules, Ending Industries’ 8-Year Wait
articles.snippet: Not since the Reagan administration has Washington moved so quickly to nullify so many federal regulations.
articles.abstract: Not since the Reagan administration has Washington moved so quickly to nullify so many federal regulations.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The document carried the title “A Roadmap to Repeal,” a concise list of Obama administration environmental regulations that a Koch brothers-backed group was pressing President Trump and Congress to quickly reverse after Inauguration Day.

articles.headline: Trump Clashes Early With Courts, Portending Years of Legal Battles
articles.snippet: The president’s attacks on a judge over an order blocking his immigration ban received condemnation in both parties but a defense from his vice president.
articles.abstract: The president’s attacks on a judge over an order blocking his immigration ban received condemnation in both parties but a defense from his vice president.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump is barreling into a confrontation with the courts barely two weeks after taking office, foreshadowing years of legal battles as an administration determined to disrupt the existing order presses the boundaries of executive power.

articles.headline: ‘This Is Us’: Why Network TV Is Feeling Hopeful
articles.snippet: The NBC series has become a breakout hit, earning an unusual two-season renewal. Insiders see the show as a counterweight to dark procedurals and darker times.
articles.abstract: The NBC series has become a breakout hit, earning an unusual two-season renewal. Insiders see the show as a counterweight to dark procedurals and darker times.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Mandy Moore and Milo Ventimiglia, stars of the NBC drama “This Is Us,” were on the set one day last month, sitting in their fictional family’s living room, as they discussed a fairly remarkable feat: how network TV can still create hits.

articles.headline: A Small Ohio Town Clamors to Curb Aggressive Policing
articles.snippet: When a black man ended up face down on the ground after a New Year’s celebration, residents of a predominantly white village were outraged.
articles.abstract: When a black man ended up face down on the ground after a New Year’s celebration, residents of a predominantly white village were outraged.
articles.lead_paragraph: YELLOW SPRINGS, Ohio — The scene was an all-too-familiar one on the streets of America’s cities: a black suspect on the ground, roughed up by white police officers as an angry crowd looked on.

articles.headline: Trump and Staff Rethink Tactics After Stumbles
articles.snippet: One thing has become apparent to both the president’s allies as well as his opponents: When it comes to governing, speed does not always guarantee success.
articles.abstract: One thing has become apparent to both the president’s allies as well as his opponents: When it comes to governing, speed does not always guarantee success.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump loves to set the day’s narrative at dawn, but the deeper story of his White House is best told at night.
articles.byline: By Glenn Thrush and Maggie Haberman

articles.headline: Not Everyone in Tech Cheers Visa Program for Foreign Workers
articles.snippet: Tech companies say the H-1B program is needed to find highly skilled employees. But it has also been used to lower labor costs and cut jobs.
articles.abstract: Tech companies say the H-1B program is needed to find highly skilled employees. But it has also been used to lower labor costs and cut jobs.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — The “knowledge transfer sessions” started a few months after Jeff Tan received notice last summer that he and about 80 co-workers would be laid off by the University of California, San Francisco, at the end of February.
articles.byline: By Daisuke Wakabayashi and Nelson D. Schwartz

articles.headline: The Massacre That Wasn’t, and a Turning Point for ‘Fake News’
articles.snippet: The internet, with the help of dogged reporting, acted quickly to shut down a Trump adviser’s false claim about a terrorist attack in Bowling Green, Ky., our media columnist writes.
articles.abstract: The internet, with the help of dogged reporting, acted quickly to shut down a Trump adviser’s false claim about a terrorist attack in Bowling Green, Ky., our media columnist writes.
articles.lead_paragraph: There were so many instant internet spoofs making fun of Kellyanne Conway’s now-famous “Bowling Green Massacre” that it’s hard to pick a favorite. Gun to my head, I’d say mine was the Twitter meme that showed a brass plaque dedicated to the names of the poor souls left for dead on Bowling Green’s grassy killing field. It was blank.

articles.headline: Escapism Reigns in Super Bowl Commercials, but Politics Proves Inescapable
articles.snippet: Many brands chose whimsy, but a few that bucked the trend with social commentary were rewarded.
articles.abstract: Many brands chose whimsy, but a few that bucked the trend with social commentary were rewarded.
articles.lead_paragraph: While many Super Bowl advertisers chose to be silly or sentimental with their commercials on Sunday, it was the few that ventured — or appeared to venture — into political territory that attracted the most attention.

articles.headline: Trump Protesters Borrow From Tea Party to Put Pressure on Lawmakers
articles.snippet: Opponents on the left are making plans to show up in force when members of Congress hold town forums during this month’s recess.
articles.abstract: Opponents on the left are making plans to show up in force when members of Congress hold town forums during this month’s recess.
articles.lead_paragraph: MORRISTOWN, N.J. — For weeks, a swelling group has been showing up every Friday here at the local office of Representative Rodney Frelinghuysen to demand that he hold a town-hall meeting to answer its concerns about his fellow Republicans’ plan to dismantle the Affordable Care Act.

articles.headline: Lifting of Travel Ban Sets Off Rush to Reach U.S.
articles.snippet: The race inundated some domestic and international airports, reunited loved ones and friends, and prompted another round of criticism from President Trump about national security.
articles.abstract: The race inundated some domestic and international airports, reunited loved ones and friends, and prompted another round of criticism from President Trump about national security.
articles.lead_paragraph: At a sweltering refugee camp on the Kenya-Somalia border, dozens of Somalis who had cleared all the final security and medical checks to enter the United States were told to prepare themselves for a flight to a new life.
articles.byline: By Caitlin Dickerson and Jeffrey Gettleman

articles.headline: Tech Opposition to Trump Propelled by Employees, Not Executives
articles.snippet: In a court filing, nearly 100 technology companies cited the “tremendous impact” of immigrants on the United States in opposing the Trump immigration ban.
articles.abstract: In a court filing, nearly 100 technology companies cited the “tremendous impact” of immigrants on the United States in opposing the Trump immigration ban.
articles.lead_paragraph: In late September, a group of tech leaders started a well-publicized effort to raise $100,000 for Hillary Clinton. In flush Silicon Valley, that is spare change. But by the time the election was over, the campaign had pulled in only $76,324.
